Dear Ms. Morrison:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
9/12/2025. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action
plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and
must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel, at (616) 204-
6992.
Sincerely,
Heather Reilly, Licensing Consultant

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
CPA Rule 400.12324 Reevaluation
(4) An agency shall document placement specifications
consistent with the information contained in the
reevaluation. The placement specifications must include
all the following: (a) The age, number, SOGIE, race,
ethnic background, and characteristics of children
preferred by the applicants.
One of three licensing files held a reassessment that did not indicate a preference
for SOGIE in the recommendation.
CPA Rule 400.12421 Visitation and family time; in person contact
(4) An agency shall facilitate in-person contact between
siblings who are not placed together except when there
is a court determination that contact is detrimental to
either child.
Two of six foster care files did not have documentation of a sibling visit for two
months of the review period. The two youth were from the same sibling group.
CPA Rule 400.12510 Independent living agreement
(2) The agreement must be signed and dated by the
youth and the social service worker. The agreement
must be reviewed with the youth at least once every 90
calendar days and a copy provided to the youth.
2

One of three independent living files did not have an IL Agreement reviewed and
signed within 90 days of the previous agreement.
REPEAT VIOLATION
11/3/2023 Interim review, CAP approved 11/8/2023.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following area:
• Borrowed Bed files: The agency was reminded to ensure that all Borrowed
Bed documents are uploaded into the provider record in CWLM.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility did not request or require consultation.
VI. EVALUATION OF PERIOD UNDER REVIEW
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has not been required to submit any corrective action plans during
this period under review.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator (CA) Annual Assessment dated 9/1/25 was reviewed and
discussed. The CA reported staff movement over the last few years, which
impacted case management and oversight. The agency reported working diligently
to address the ripple effect caused by those changes. The CA reported they have
faced challenges due to an increased population of youth with significant mental
health needs and high-risk behaviors. The agency has made intensive efforts to
work with multiple systems within MDHHS to ensure youth receive the services
needed. The CA reported the addition of new supports and services was beneficial
to youth, caregivers, and staff. The CA reported there were three placement
disruptions during this review period. All three were due to youth having
complicated trauma and placement histories. Attempts were made to provide
support and additional services. However, the placements could not be
maintained. One youth moved to a relative caregiver, one moved to residential
treatment, and the third moved with fictive kin.
3

Although the agency did not have a CAP from the 2024 review, the CA identified
monthly case worker visits and timely medical and dental exams as areas to
continue improving compliance.
Financial Overview
Not applicable.
Staff Interviews
Two staff were interviewed on site. Staff had been with the agency between 4-8
years. Both staff reported they enjoyed their positions and felt supported by their
supervisor. Staff stated they were able to discuss any concerns with administration
and overall felt supported in their positions. Regarding concerns or suggestions for
improvement, staff reported that some mandatory in-person training would be
more beneficial if it were online. Workers stated it is difficult to devote an entire
day to training over material they are already familiar with, when they have so
many demands on their time.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The agency continues to be located in the same office building as 2024. The
building has sufficient space for staff and clients to meet and conduct visitation.
There is adequate locking storage for files and confidential documentation.
VII. AGENCY ANALYST FINDINGS
There were four identified safety alerts.
Safety Alert #1: During a visit on 7/8/25 the Agency Analyst observed a smoke
detector was missing from the basement.
Resolution #1: The agency contacted the family on 7/8/25. The family
immediately replaced the smoke alarm, and a photo was provided to DCWL for
verification.
Safety Alert #2: During a visit on 7/9/25 the Agency Analyst observed a
basement bedroom without a second means of egress. An approved variance
was not on file.
Resolution #2: The agency contacted the family on 7/9/25 and developed a
safety plan. The licensee's adult son was utilizing the basement bedroom. The
plan stated that he agreed to sleep in an upstairs bedroom and the basement
room would be for storage only. Photos of the bedrooms were provided to DCWL
for verification.
Safety Alert #3: During a visit on 7/10/25 the Agency Analyst observed a smoke
detector on the first floor that was not working.
Resolution #3: The foster family had a smoke detector that needed new
batteries. The batteries were installed, and the smoke detector was mounted on
the wall. A photo was provided to DCWL for verification.
4

Safety Alert #4: On 7/16/25 the Agency Analyst observed two non-working
smoke detectors. One on the first floor and one on the second.
Resolution #4: The non-working smoke detectors were removed, and new ones
were installed. An agency foster care worker tested both new smoke detectors to
confirm they worked. A photo was provided to DCWL for verification.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. A CAP is required.
